This year, The Fralin Art Museum in Charlottesville welcomed over 3,500 Writer’s Eye participants from Charlottesville, Richmond, Staunton, and Waynesboro, and eight surrounding counties, and received 1,296 entries to the annual literary competition. Congratulations are extended to Tye River Elementary School's Faculty, Staff and Students who have earned a much deserved award from the Virginia Department of Education. Way to Go Tye River Tigers!

The school was awarded the 2019 Board of Education Continuous Improvement Award.

To earn the Board of Education Continuous Achievement Award, a school must earn a state accreditation rating of Accredited or Accredited with Conditions and meet at least one of the following benchmarks for improved performance on accreditation-related school quality indicators:

 A cumulative 10-point increase over three years in the combined rates for reading and mathematics and in the pass rate for science, with improvement each year on each indicator:

 A cumulative 10-point increase over three years in the combined rates for reading and mathematics for two or more student groups, with improvement each year for each group on
both indicators; or

 A cumulative 15-percent decrease in the chronic absenteeism rate over three years, with a decrease each year.

Here is some information on the Destination Imagination program:

Their VISION:
To teach students the creative process and empower them with the skills needed to succeed in an ever-changing world.

Their MISSION:
To develop opportunities that inspire the global community of learners to utilize diverse approaches in applying 21st century skills and creativity.

The Destination Imagination program is a fun, hands-on system of learning that fosters students’ creativity, courage and curiosity through open-ended academic Challenges in the fields of STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics), fine arts and service learning. Participants learn patience, flexibility, persistence, ethics, respect for others and their ideas, and the collaborative problem solving process.

The Marching Governors had another great day this past Saturday in Princeton, WV at the 9th annual Southern Thunder Band Festival. Our marching band captured first place in class AA-2 and won the Grand Championship trophy for Division 1.
The color guard continued an undefeated season by capturing their third straight first place trophy. Drum Major Lauren Canody won third place drum major, and the Nelson County percussion section won first place in class AA.The Marching Governors have now brought home 18 trophies in three competitions.

The journey continues this coming Saturday and the road gets much much tougher at the Shenandoah Valley Invitational at Harrisonburg High School. The band lineup looks like a Virginia Whos Who of Marching Bands. Nelson performs at 3:45 PM. Please come show your support for your Marching Governors!

Deadline for students to apply is February 1, 2016. Program information and application can be found on this website, blast.spacegrant.org.

Overwhelmed by the thought of planning for college? You're not alone! Join other students and parents for College Night—a free, college-planning event being held at Nelson County High School on Wednesday, October 21 from 5:30-7:30 pm. Pizza will be served starting at 5:30, and then you will have the chance to attend two of three workshops focusing on choosing the right college, paying for college, and scholarships.

You'll get straight answers and simple strategies, and three lucky seniors will receive a $500 scholarship. This is an opportunity for you to talk to professionals who will take the mystery out of financial aid and guide you through the process of planning and paying for college. College Night can help you start to see college as an affordable, attainable goal—and give you the tools to get there.

We are hopeful that the recent Virginia Supreme Court ruling that Sweet Briar College can be considered a trust will allow the courts to give the college a fighting chance to keep its doors open. We are impressed with the drive and tenacity of Sweet Briar alumnae who have risen to the occasion and are the driving force in the fight to preserve their historic Alma mater. Education should be cherished by all in our society, and as such, institutions of higher learning should be valued and supported by their communities to allow future generations to benefit from their offerings.

Thank-you SBC family for reminding us that we don't have to be complacent when injustice befalls us. We do have a voice and it should be used to protect and preserve those things we value and hold dear.... education and its priceless rewards should be one of them.

Happy Thanksgiving to you and your family.

Congratulations to Nelson County High School for having been named a Blue Star School!

Working in Support of Education (WISE), an educational non-profit, recently announced that 148 Virginia public schools were named Blue Star Schools for their students performance on the 2013-2014 WISE Financial Literacy Certification test. This national standardized test is administered to students at the end of a course on personal finance. Students passing the test earn the WISE Certified Financially Literate designation, which demonstrates that they are financially capable when they graduate.

To earn the Blue Star recognition, a school must achieve a 75-percent pass rate on the test and have either a majority of students in a particular grade level take the test or have the students who took the test achieve an average score of 80 percent or higher.

The Virginia Space Grant Consortium would like to share the following information about the following FREE NASA-related programs for Virginia's high school students interested in STEM.

Virginia Aerospace Science and Technology Scholars (VASTS) is a NASA-based program for 11th grade students and STEM teachers who are interested in aerospace-related science, technology, engineering and/or math (STEM). This course focuses on space mission design and human space flight.

For more information, please go to the following website: http://www.vasts.spacegrant.org. The deadline for the application is November 2, 2014.

In addition, Virginia Space Coast Scholars is a NASA-based STEM program for 10th grade students who are interested in NASA's space and Earth and airborne science-related missions.

The deadline for the application is also November 2, 2014.
